We‚Äôre not chasing market share ‚Äî we‚Äôre redesigning how 100M+ urban residents experience daily commerce.

The next decade belongs to businesses that shift behaviour, not follow it.

Headline: Fueling business momentum with strategic expertise and bold initiatives!
Comment:
Most founders don‚Äôt realise that the real upside today isn‚Äôt in fighting for share, it‚Äôs in creating demand that didn‚Äôt exist yesterday. In almost every category I‚Äôve worked with, the ceiling isn‚Äôt competition, it‚Äôs imagination. Consumers are evolving faster than the products meant for them.
And the real unlock is this: category creators don‚Äôt ask how big the market is. They ask why the market hasn‚Äôt been built yet. That single shift separates builders from transformers.
If there‚Äôs one truth the next decade will reward, it‚Äôs this. Entering an old race makes you a participant. Creating a new one makes you the benchmark others chase.

Headline: CMO-Fractional | Brand Builder & Strategic Marketing Consultant | LinkedIn TopVoice | Mentor, IIM Calcutta Innovation Park
Comment:
The red ocean vs blue ocean dilemma. Jumping onto a very red ocean with strong players already playing is a thought game - even though the market size is huge and gaining even a minuscule percentage may be a huge revenue. 
Creating blue oceans may not be every founder‚Äôs cup of tea. 
But I think what works best is being a  third or fourth player in a red ocean  - and promising substantial value upgrade than existing players is a winner strategy - because changing consumer behaviours from 0-1 is most difficult - but once they are used to a product/ service  - upgrading them to the next high value product is easier.
